metadata.titleEn: The slope aspect map of the Tibetan Plateau (2000)
metadata.description:
This data set contains the digital slope aspect distribution and slope aspect degree data of the Tibetan Plateau, which can be used to assist in basic geographic information analysis and research work on the Tibetan Plateau region. 
The raw data were the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) data provided by Global Land Cover Network (GLCN) using the WGS84 coordinate system, and the raw data were framing data, including latitude and longitude data, with a spatial resolution of 3″. After the mosaic processing, the Nodata (null data) generated in the mosaic process were interpolated and filled, and after filling, a projection conversion process was performed to generate an equal-area conical projection of the data bit Albers, after conversion projection, the spatial resolution was 90 m. Finally, the boundary of the Tibetan Plateau was used for cutting to obtain DEM data. Use the spatial analysis module under ArcMap to calculate the slope aspect and generate the slope aspect map. 
Pixel data: value
Data type: floating point
Interpretation: slope degree
Dimension: degree
Data accuracy: spatial resolution 90 m

authorList.unitEn: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations

literatureList.referenceEn: Farr, T.G., Rosen, P.A., Caro, E., Crippen, R., Duren, R., Hensley, S., Kobrick, M., Paller, M., Rodriguez, E., Roth, L., Seal, D., Shaffer, S., Shimada, J., Umland, J., Werner, M., Oskin, M., Burbank, D., Alsdorf, D. (2007). The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission, Rev. Geophys., 45, RG2004. https://doi.org/10.1029/2005RG000183

background: The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission produced the most complete, highest-resolution digital elevation model of the Earth. The project was a joint endeavor of NASA, the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency, and the German and Italian Space Agencies and flew in February 2000. At the foundation of modern geosciences, quite literally, is knowledge of the shape of the Earth’s surface. Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality: some with astounding accuracy, some far less adequate. It has proven exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means. The emergence, in the 1990s, of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry placed the possibility of efficiently and affordably creating a global digital elevation model within the grasp of spacefaring nations. Interferometric SAR, or InSAR, makes use of phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio (typically 0.0002) to measure topography.
research objective: The SRTM objective was to acquire a digital elevation model of all land between about 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude, about 80% of Earth’s land surface. The operational goal of C radar was to generate contiguous mapping coverage as called for by the mission objectives. X radar was included as an experimental demonstration. As it did not employ ScanSAR, the X band radar had a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) than the C band system. The key to successful acquisition of a data set suitable for automated production is to remove the variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations and to measure the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects accurately at all times during data acquisition.
challenges: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality: some with astounding accuracy, some far less adequate. Furthermore, the global coverage has been uneven. It has proven exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means. Optical stereo mapping systems suffer from poor control and matching difficulties in areas of low contrast and from persistent cloud cover in many important areas of the world.
methods: Following the launch, the first 12 hours of flight were taken up by on-orbit checkout (OOCO), during which the payload bay doors were opened, the SRTM system was activated and checked, and the orbiter was maneuvered to the mapping attitude. Mapping continued for 149 orbits (222.4 hours). Data were acquired at the rate of 180 megabits per second (Mbps) (C radar) and at 90 Mbps (X radar). Selected snapshots of data necessary for near-real-time performance assessment were down linked via the shuttle Ku band and NASA’s tracking and data relay system (TDRS) link to JPL in Pasadena and to the Payload Operations Control Center (POCC) in Houston.
dataset: A total of 765 data takes were executed. Of these, 399 were C radar only, 1 was X radar only, and 365 were simultaneous C and X radar. The volume of data produced by SRTM, 12.3 Tb (8.6 Tb by C radar, 3.7 Tb by X radar), compares to the capacity of the Library of Congress.

Verification.Question: Does the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) use synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry for data collection?
Is the spatial resolution of the generated slope map data 90 meters after projection conversion?
Were there challenges in producing a digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution using conventional methods?

Disjunctive.Question: Are digital elevation models for topographic mapping primarily sourced from synthetic aperture radar (SAR), optical stereo mapping systems, or other technologies?
Which data collection method faces more challenges due to low contrast and cloud cover: optical stereo mapping systems or interferometric SAR (InSAR)?

In the context of acquiring a digital elevation model, is it more challenging to maintain consistent scale and resolution through conventional topographic mapping technologies or through SAR interferometry?

Concept Completion.Question: What is the primary data source used for generating digital elevation models in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau region?
What challenges are associated with conventional topographic mapping technologies in creating global digital elevation models?
Where is the data transformation process applied to convert radar data into a suitable projection for spatial analysis?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to create a digital elevation model of the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) used synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry to create a digital elevation model, which involves phase-difference measurements from two radar images acquired with a small base to height ratio to measure topography.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting data for a global digital elevation model?
Example.Answer: A significant challenge in collecting data for a global digital elevation model is the uneven quality of conventional topographic mapping technologies, which can produce maps with varying accuracy and are also affected by persistent cloud cover in many areas.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset that resulted from radar data acquisition during a topographic mapping mission?
Example.Answer: The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) produced a dataset with a total of 765 data takes, including 399 C radar only, 1 X radar only, and 365 simultaneous C and X radar, resulting in a data volume of 12.3 Tb.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the data collection methods used for creating a digital elevation model of the Earth's surface?
Feature Specification.Answer: synthetic aperture radar interferometry, Interferometric SAR, phase-difference measurements, C radar, X radar, 180 Mbps, 90 Mbps

Feature Specification.Question: What are the challenges associated with creating a global digital elevation model using conventional topographic mapping technologies?
Feature Specification.Answer: uneven quality, difficulties in creating a consistent scale and resolution globally, high expenses, poor control, matching difficulties in areas of low contrast, persistent cloud cover

Quantification.Question: How many data takes were executed during the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission for creating digital elevation models?
What was the volume of data produced by the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission using C and X radar?
What is the spatial resolution of the final DEM data used for the Tibetan Plateau slope aspect map?

Definition.Question: What is interferometric SAR (InSAR) in the context of digital elevation model creation?
Definition.Answer: Interferometric SAR, or InSAR, is a technique that uses phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio to measure topography. This method was pivotal in efficiently and affordably creating a global digital elevation model, as demonstrated by the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM).

Definition.Question: What challenges are commonly faced when using conventional topographic mapping technologies?
Definition.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies often produce maps of uneven quality, with some being highly accurate and others less adequate. Additionally, global coverage has been uneven, and producing a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution has proven to be difficult and expensive. Optical stereo mapping systems also face issues such as poor control, matching difficulties in areas of low contrast, and problems with cloud cover in many regions.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of data collection rates in the context of radar mapping missions?
Definition.Answer: During radar mapping missions such as the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission, data collection rates are critical for achieving the mission objectives. For example, data were acquired at the rate of 180 megabits per second (Mbps) for C radar and 90 Mbps for X radar. These rates were necessary to ensure that data suitable for automated production was acquired efficiently, allowing for near-real-time performance assessment and achieving high-resolution digital elevation models.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for creating a digital elevation model using Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) data compare to conventional topographic mapping technologies?
Comparison.Answer: SRTM data collection uses synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry, which efficiently and affordably creates a global digital elevation model, while conventional methods have produced maps of uneven quality and are difficult and expensive to implement consistently at a global scale.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data quality and challenges between using C radar and X radar in the context of digital elevation model creation?
Comparison.Answer: C radar aimed to generate contiguous mapping coverage as per mission objectives, while X radar, used experimentally, had a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) due to not employing ScanSAR. C radar data volume was larger than X radar, posing different data management challenges.

Comparison.Question: How does the spatial resolution of the digital elevation model generated from SRTM data compare to the spatial resolution after processing and conversion for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau slope aspect map?
Comparison.Answer: The original SRTM data had a spatial resolution of 3 arc-seconds, which after processing and conversion to Albers equal-area conic projection for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, resulted in a spatial resolution of 90 meters, reflecting a transformation in data granularity suitable for regional analysis.

Interpretation.Question: What strategies can be employed to address the shortcomings of conventional topographic mapping technologies in producing global map sets of consistent scale and resolution?
Interpretation.Answer: Strategies to address these shortcomings include leveraging SAR interferometry for its phase-difference measurements, handling pass-to-pass variability, and utilizing advanced radar systems with better signal-to-noise ratios. These approaches help overcome the uneven quality and coverage issues faced by conventional mapping technologies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to produce a global digital elevation model using conventional means?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: It has proven exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means. The challenges include uneven quality of maps produced by conventional topographic mapping technologies, and the global coverage has been uneven. Additionally, optical stereo mapping systems face issues like poor control, matching difficulties in areas of low contrast, and persistent cloud cover in many important areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes variability and decorrelation in data acquisition for digital elevation models, and how does this impact the production process?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The key to successful acquisition of a data set suitable for automated production is to remove the variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations. Variability and decorrelation can impact the accuracy and reliability of the data set by introducing inconsistencies. Accurate measurement of the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects at all times during data acquisition is crucial to mitigate these issues.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential data quality outcomes when using interferometric SAR (InSAR) techniques in digital elevation modeling over traditional topographic mapping technologies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of interferometric SAR (InSAR) techniques in digital elevation modeling can result in more consistent scale and resolution compared to traditional topographic mapping technologies, which often produce maps of uneven quality and accuracy.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of uneven global coverage in optical stereo mapping systems on the generation of a comprehensive digital elevation model?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Uneven global coverage in optical stereo mapping systems can result in challenges such as poor control, matching difficulties in areas of low contrast, and limitations due to persistent cloud cover, which complicate the creation of a comprehensive and consistent digital elevation model.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to create a digital elevation model specifically for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau region using the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The creation of a digital elevation model for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau aids in foundational geographic information analysis, enabling more accurate understanding and research of the region's topography, which is crucial given its unique and complex terrain.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended benefits of utilizing synthetic aperture radar interferometry in generating a digital elevation model?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The use of synthetic aperture radar interferometry allows for efficient and affordable creation of a global digital elevation model with consistent scale and resolution, overcoming the limitations of conventional topographic mapping technologies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What was the primary objective of acquiring a digital elevation model covering 80% of Earth's land surface from the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective was to acquire comprehensive digital elevation data of all land between 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude, thereby providing a contiguous and reliable dataset crucial for automated production and various geographical and scientific analyses.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can synthetic aperture radar interferometry be utilized to create a global digital elevation model efficiently?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Interferometric SAR, or InSAR, makes use of phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio (typically 0.0002) to measure topography. This method enables the efficient and affordable creation of a global digital elevation model.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to address the challenges of variability and decorrelation in radar data acquisition for topographic mapping?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The key to successful acquisition of a data set suitable for automated production is to remove the variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations and to measure the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects accurately at all times during data acquisition.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the efficient creation of global digital elevation models?
Enablement.Answer: The emergence of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry in the 1990s made it possible to efficiently and affordably create a global digital elevation model. Interferometric SAR, or InSAR, uses phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images to measure topography, allowing spacefaring nations to overcome the limitations of conventional topographic mapping technologies.

Enablement.Question: How do specific data collection methods overcome challenges related to consistent scale and resolution in digital elevation models?
Enablement.Answer: The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission aimed to acquire a digital elevation model of all land between about 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude. The use of both C radar and X radar, with the latter having a higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio, helped in generating contiguous mapping coverage despite challenges associated with conventional methods, such as variability and decorrelation in pass-to-pass observations.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for the successful acquisition of datasets suitable for automated production in topographic mapping?
Enablement.Answer: For successful acquisition of a dataset suitable for automated production in topographic mapping, it is crucial to remove the variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations and to measure the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects accurately during data acquisition. This ensures the data set can be efficiently processed and utilized for mapping.

Expectation.Question: Why might researchers expect challenges in generating a global digital elevation model with consistent scale and resolution using conventional mapping techniques?
Expectation.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality, with some having astounding accuracy and others being far less adequate. Additionally, the global coverage has been uneven, making it exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means.

Expectation.Question: What are the expectations regarding the challenges faced by optical stereo mapping systems in producing reliable data in specific regions?
Expectation.Answer: Optical stereo mapping systems are expected to face challenges due to poor control and matching difficulties in areas of low contrast and persistent cloud cover in many important areas of the world.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to accurately measure the interferometer baseline and systematic effects during data acquisition for creating a digital elevation model?
Expectation.Answer: Accurate measurement of the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects is crucial to remove the variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations, which is key to the successful acquisition of a dataset suitable for automated production.

Judgmental.Question: What are the main challenges in achieving global coverage with digital elevation models, and how can they be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges in achieving global coverage with digital elevation models include the difficulty and expense of producing consistent scale and resolution maps using conventional methods, and issues such as poor control and matching difficulties in optical stereo mapping systems. These challenges can be addressed by employing advanced techniques like synthetic aperture radar interferometry, which offer better control and resolution across a wider range of conditions.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can data acquisition processes be optimized to support automated production of digital elevation models?
Judgmental.Answer: Data acquisition processes can be optimized by removing variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations, accurately measuring the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects, and ensuring continuous data collection. This approach, as demonstrated by the SRTM, helps in generating a data set suitable for automated production, facilitating the creation of high-quality digital elevation models.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure why the variability and decorrelation from pass-to-pass observations pose such a challenge in creating a consistent digital elevation model.
Assertion.Answer: The variability and decorrelation from pass-to-pass observations make it difficult to consistently measure the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects accurately, which are critical for creating a reliable digital elevation model.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how the spaceborne SAR interferometry technique significantly improves the data collection process for digital elevation models.
Assertion.Answer: Spaceborne SAR interferometry, or InSAR, allows for efficient and affordable creation of digital elevation models by using phase-difference measurements from radar images to measure topography, which is more consistent and scalable than conventional methods.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used to acquire digital elevation models for large geographic areas using radar technology.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods involved using Interferometric SAR (InSAR) technology, which takes advantage of phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio. The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) used C and X band radars to map the Earth's land surface between 60° north and 56° south latitudes. Data were acquired at high rates and transmitted to ground stations for processing.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the challenges faced in creating consistent and high-resolution global digital elevation models using radar interferometry.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges included producing maps of uneven quality with conventional topographic mapping technologies and the difficulty and cost of achieving global coverage with consistent scale and resolution. Optical systems faced issues with control and matching in areas of low contrast and persistent cloud cover. The SRTM project had to address variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations and ensure accurate measurement of the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential methods for enhancing the spatial resolution and accuracy of digital elevation models derived from radar data.
Request/Directive.Answer: Enhancing spatial resolution and accuracy could involve improving the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of radar systems, as demonstrated by the slightly higher resolution of X band radar compared to C band in the SRTM project. Another approach may include refining interferometric processing techniques to better handle variability and decorrelation in radar data. Additionally, integrating multiple data sources or advanced algorithms for interpolation and projection conversion may further improve model quality.
